title: ompulsory voting
intro: For those who are able to vote, should we be made to do it? Listen to Rob and Finn discussing why we should all exercise our right to vote and especially by young people – whilst teaching some related vocabulary.
this_week_question: What is a constituency? Is it …
a) the people who live in and vote in a particular area?
b) the politicians who make and change the laws of a country?
c) a town or district that has its own government?
You can hear the right answer at the end of the programme.

vocab.desc: a vote for a government that runs the whole country
something that you have to do
something you have a responsibility to do
compulsory government service that usually means military service
finishing something difficult or unpleasant as quickly as possible

vocab.text: pick (a political party) out of a hat
vocab.desc: to choose randomly rather than making an informed choice

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Rob…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: … and I'm Neil. Hello.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hello, Neil! Today we're talking about voting. Now I'm sure it's something you've done Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Of course – and earlier this year we had a general election in the UK where I voted. And I'd feel guilty if I didn't exercise my right to vote. Now a right in this case means somebody's legal claim to vote.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: In a general election we vote for a government that runs the whole country, but we also have local and European elections too sometimes.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes but voting in the UK is optional – so you don't have to do it, whereas in some countries voting is compulsory - and compulsory means something that you have to do.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So if you were in Australia, where the government passed a law that made voting compulsory, you would have had to pay a fine of $20 for not voting.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And that's because the Australian government believes that voting is a duty and not just a right.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Duty means something you have a responsibility to do.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And it's your duty Rob to ask me today's quiz question!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, sir! So can you tell me, what is a constituency? Is it …

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well I'm no expert on politics… but I'm going to go for c) that's a town or district that has its own government.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK. Well, we'll find out later on in the show whether you're right or wrong. Now it's time to hear what a truly young person has to say about compulsory voting.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh right, unlike me you mean? Well, here's Michael Yip, who is a student at Warwick University and therefore much younger than me.

transcript.author: Michael Yip, student at Warwick University
transcript.text: A lot of the people that I speak to just say 'I don’t care' or 'I don't really know what's going on' and in this way, another reason why I'm quite cautious about this is because it could sort of engender this sort of slapdash attitude towards politics where you know it’s sort of seen as, you know, being conscripted for national service … you just want to get it over and done with.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So Michael says he is cautious about the idea of introducing compulsory voting. So why is that, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: He thinks forcing young people to vote will engender – or give rise to – a slapdash attitude. Now what does slapdash mean, Rob?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: It's a good word, isn't it? It means doing something quickly and carelessly.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh you've never do that, would you? Now, Michael compares compulsory voting to national service. National service is compulsory government service that usually means military service and is also known as conscription .

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So when it's something you haven't chosen to do, or which you actively don't want to do – it's a case of getting it over and done with .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And that means finishing something difficult or unpleasant as quickly as possible.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Young people might just pick a political party out of a hat – which means to choose randomly – rather than making an informed choice.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So some people think that politicians need to improve political education. Now let's listen to broadcaster and writer Rick Edwards talking about this.

transcript.author: Rick Edwards, broadcaster and writer
transcript.text: If you said to politicians, 'Right, 3.3 million first-time voters are definitely going to vote', then they will have to speak to them and they will have to make an effort to go to where they are and I think that's the change it would create.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So compulsory voting would mean a responsibility for the politicians too.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That's right. They need to engage and educate young people. Otherwise reluctant voters may deliberately spoil – or waste – their votes.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: The government could also include a 'none of the above' option on the ballot paper.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Can you explain a bit more about that Rob?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, it means you tick this option if you don't want to vote for any of the listed political parties.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: An interesting idea. Well my option for now is to get the answer to the quiz question.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, well, I asked: What is a constituency? Is it … a) the people who live in and vote in a particular area? b) the politicians who make and change the laws of a country? Or c) a town or district that has its own government?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I said c) a town or district that has its own government.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, you ticked the wrong box, Neil! The answer is a) the people who live in and vote in a particular area. Now, did you know the UK is currently divided into 650 areas called parliamentary constituencies, each of which is represented by one MP in the House of Commons? And each constituency can have a different area. The largest is Ross, Skye and Lochaber in Scotland measuring approximately 12,000 square kilometres. The smallest constituency is Islington North in London measuring a little over seven square kilometres. Now, can we hear today's words again please, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK. We heard:

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Splendid! Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. I hope it got your vote! You can hear more programmes at bbclearningenglish.com . Please join us again soon.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.
